In this investigation, co-precipitation (Cp) and sol gel (Sg) technique were employed to fabricate CoFe2O4, CuFe2O4, NiAl2O4 and NiFe2O4 mixed oxide catalysts. The catalytic activity of these catalysts in methane combustion was studied at temperature range of 300 to 550 °C and gas hourly space velocity of 14,000 h − 1. Different analyses including the X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption (BET), Energy Dispersive X-Ray Analysis (EDX), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and H2-TPR analysis were used in order to investigate the structural properties of the catalysts. The small crystal size improves the surface area and catalyst active site, thus increasing the rate of reaction and conversion factor. The results revealed that the method of preparation had an important role in controlling the structural features of the catalysts, resulting in an important difference in catalytic presentation. The reactor tests required CO2 selectivity of 100% for all synthesized catalysts, and the best catalytic activity (97% methane conversion) and structural properties (surface area of 41.81 m2 g − 1 and crystal size of 13.20 nm) was demonstrated by CoFe2O4 (co-precipitation) sample. It was also revealed that catalysts synthesized using sol gel method had agglomeration impact on the surface of the catalyst, leading to an increase in crystalline size and a decrease in catalytic activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalytic methane combustion Cobalt oxide Mixed oxide catalysts Preparation method Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nowadays, the constantly increasing demand for energy is among the main concerns over economic growth and social development. Because of its large quantities in the world and its high calorific value, natural gas is widely used in power generation and heating applications. Methane, as the main component of natural gas, is an important clean energy with low nitrogen and sulfur contaminants [1–4].Methane combustion requires high temperatures, up to 1400 °C, for complete combustion. In this process, the nitrogen in air and the traces of nitrogen and sulfur in natural gas can be oxidized into harmful NOx and SOx[5,6]. Incomplete combustion causes unburned methane to be released, causing a greenhouse effect 20 times as much as CO2. NOx formation can be reduced by employing catalytic combustion to lower the temperatures of methane combustion. The important issue is to make a high-efficiency and stable catalyst that can promise the complete combustion of methane at low temperatures. Compared to the conventional flame combustion, the presence of certain catalysts may lead to a decrease in the working temperature (<1400 °C). The operational temperature for catalytic methane combustion (CMC) can be divided into a relatively lower range (about 300–700 °C) and a relatively higher one (about 700–1400 °C), depending on the target application. [7]. Due to the remarkable abatement of pollutant emissions and prolonged catalyst lifetime, low temperature CMC becomes more attractive. For example, the reusability and reproducibility of catalysts, particularly for noble metal catalysts, are shortened at high temperatures. In this regard, the challenging issue is to make catalysts which have high catalytic activity, low light-off temperature and good thermal stability even for such low temperature operations [8]. Eq (1) shows the main equation of methane combustion: (1) C H 4 + 2 O 2 ↔ C O 2 + 2 H 2 Δ H 298 = − 802.7 Kj / mol The common catalysts for this process could be divided into two groups: novel metal catalysts and metal oxides. The former (Pd, Pt, Au, etc.) have high catalytic activity [9–13], but they are very expensive. The Pd and Pd supported on ϒ-Al2O3 are the most interesting catalytic materials for methane combustion, which show high activity and acceptable active phase thermo stability [14]. These metals are very active catalysts for complete oxidation of hydrocarbons. As mentioned above, owing to their high activities, palladium and platinum are reported to be the most extensively employed metals for complete oxidation of methane [15–17]. In recent studies, with regard to higher activities of Pd compared to Pt, Pd is in the center of attention for methane oxidation. Kumar et al. investigated the behavior of palladium at high temperatures in methane combustion. Pd/CeZrO2 and Pd/LaFeO3 catalysts have provided better Pd dispersion in Pd/CeZrO2 catalysts and they have shown more stability and activity in the same temperature range. In addition, Jong et al. have investigated the effect of NiO addition to alumina-based palladium catalyst to achieve a higher conversion rate of methane. It has been concluded that NiO can adsorb and release due to its cubic structure and the amount of oxygen increases in the catalyst [18–21]. The transition metal oxides (CoOx, NiO, CuO, Cr2O3, and MnOx), spinel oxides, and Perovskites-type catalysts as non-noble metal catalysts are more desirable since the limitation in abundance of noble metals and their high cost have no chance for further industrialization [22–30]. Metal oxides are more economical than noble metals. High conversion of metal oxides such as TiO2, ZnO, Co3O4, and Fe3O4 make them proper for low-temperature oxidation reactions. Moreover, such materials are usually reduced through losing their lattice oxygen at moderate temperatures (< 500 °C). The easy reduction of reducible metal oxides has a major impact on the long-term stability for methane combustion or reforming [28,31-38]. The following factors including reactor temperature, the ratio of oxygen/ methane, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV), amount of catalyst loading, and some catalytic process like particular surface area, and crystal size are important in methane combustion; and the uniform catalyst distribution affects catalyst combustion of methane [35,39,40]. Transition metal ions are the activation centers of gaseous oxygen by changing the valence state. The capability for oxygen activation is influenced by crystalline structure of the metal oxide. Moreover, the catalysts for catalytic combustion of methane such as simple transition metal oxides could be employed with high catalytic activity [41,42]. Recently, the CoFe2O4 has gained attention because of its low cost and suitable chemical stability [43,44]. Li et al. [45] prepared the MFe2O4(M = Co, Ni, Cu, Mn) nanofibers using the electrospinning technique; and after consequent heat treatment, it was demonstrated that CoFe2O4 quasi-nanofibers show the highest catalytic activity for H2O2 reduction in alkaline environment. Obviously, these materials are usually gained after calcination at high temperature, but they lead to a low surface area. Consequently, the development of an efficient technique to produce catalysts with porous structures and high surface area is urgently needed. For example, Dumitrou et al. [46] synthesized mesoporous cobalt ferrite and found out that the porous materials displayed suitable catalytic activity for lean methane combustion. Ueda et al. [47] produced 3DOM MFe2O4 (M = Zn, Ni, Co) samples using polystyrene colloidal crystal molding technique with ethylene glycol as solvent. Li et al. [48] also approved a similar technique to find 3DOM CoFe2O4 and proved that it displayed suitable electrochemical performance in Li-ion battery. In addition, Li et al. [49]. investigated the catalytic presentation for methane combustion of 3DOM CoFe2O4 by co-loading MnOx and Pd–Pt alloy nanoparticles. They demonstrated that the as-prepared samples showed a surface area of 19–28 m2/g, a high-quality 3DOM structure (103 ± 20 nm in pore size), and the noble metal or alloy nanoparticles (NPs) with a size of 2.2–3.0 nm were uniformly dispersed on the macropore wall surface of 3DOM CoFe2O4. According to our results, it is obviously achieving more optimum conditions for combustion of methane with higher surface area, pore size, and consequently more conversion response for suggested catalyst. In this study, we set out to evaluate the impact of synthesis method (co-precipitation and sol-gel) and transition metals (Fe, Co, Cu, and Ni) on the combustion activity of methane. Catalytic combustion reaction has been performed under constant feed condition at a fix temperature range 300–550 °C. Methane conversion of each catalysis has been investigated to provide suitable catalysis for methane combustion reaction. In the co-precipitation method, it has better mixing and its industrial application is more than that of the other synthesis method. Bonds are better performed at the molecular scale. In fact, NiAl2O4 was the first synthesized sample which was then promoted by substitution of Al with Fe; moreover, to promote the catalytic presentation, Cu and Co were also used as compared to Ni. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Raw materials The materials applied in this study are: Aluminum Nitrate Al(NO3)3·9H2O (Loba Chemie, 99.95%), Ferric Nitrate Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (Loba Chemie, 99.95%), Cobalt Nitrate Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Loba Chemie, 99.95%), Nickel Nitrate Ni(NO3)3·6H2O (Loba Chemie, 99.95%), Copper Nitrate Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Loba Chemie, 99.95%) and potassium carbonate (Loba Chemie, 99.95%) without any further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Different catalysts including CoFe2O4, CuFe2O4, NiAl2O4 and NiFe2O4 were prepared by Co-precipitation and sol-gel methods. In a typical synthesis of AB2O4 spinel catalyst, a suitable amount of A and B as metal and nitrate salt was, respectively, dissolved in distilled water. Precipitation agents such as metal salts and sodium carbonate were then applied. The solutions were placed in two burettes, and during precipitation, the pH was kept at about 9.The precipitates were aged by stirring at room temperature for 8 h, then dried at 80 °C for 12 h and finally calcined at 500 °C for 4 h [50]. The CoFe2O4 and CuFe2O4 catalysts were fabricated via sol-gel method to compare with the sample synthesized by co-precipitation method. Cobalt Nitrate Co(NO3)3·6H2O and Ferric Nitrate Fe(NO3)3·9H2O mixed in 2-Methoxyethonal were under constant magnetic stirring for a few minutes. After that, NH3 was added to the precursor solution in order to maintain the pH of the solution about 11. Acetic acid and ethylene glycol were added to the solution in a molar ratio of 1:1. The clear sol was completely turned to a gel. After continuous stirring for 4 h at 80 °C, the gel was dried and ground into powders before being calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffractometer method (PANalytical, X'Pert-Pro, Wavelength of x-ray beam (Cu Kα): 1.54 angstrom, Anode material: Cu Voltage: 40 kV Current: 30 mA) by scanning rate 0.05 2 θ / s was employed to investigate the evaluation of the crystalline sizes and phase composition. Scattering intensities were determined over the angular range 2 θ = 10 − 80 0 . Crystalline sizes were gained by Scherrer's equation as follows: (2) d = 0.9 λ β . c o s θ Where, d is the crystalline size, λ shows the X-ray wavelength, β and θ stand for line broadening at half the maximum intensity (FWHM) and the Bragg angle, respectively. The surface morphology of the suggested catalysts was investigated by scanning electron microscopy analysis (SEM) using a Nova Nano SEM 650 instrument. N2 adsorption–desorption analysis (BET) was performed by an automatic gas adsorption analyzer (Tristar 3020, Micrometrics) at the boiling temperature of nitrogen (−196 °C) 2.4 Catalytic activity tests Catalyst activity for methane combustion reaction was done by quartz fixed-bed reactor with 8 mm inner diameter. The mass of the catalyst was 200 mg with 40–60 mesh. The reaction temperature was improved from 300 °C to 550 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1, and the data point was carried out. After that, each temperature point was stabilized for 30 min. The feed gas mixture contained 4 mol.% CH4, 8 mol.% O2 balanced with Ar, and total feed (dry) flow rate was 47 ml/min, and GHSV was kept at 14,000 h − 1. Before each test, the catalysts were oxidized under pure oxygen stream (30 ml/min) at 300 °C and atmospheric pressure for 1 h. The outlet gas composition and concentration were evaluated on-line by a gas chromatograph (GC), Shimadzu-8A (Carbosieve column), with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). BFD Experimental set up is shown in Fig. 1 . The gas in the capsule enters the reactor through pipelines. By using MFC, the flow required for the flow is measured and controlled. After passing through the MFC, the gas flow enters the reactor and then the gas flow coming out of the reactor enters the condenser to separate the water vapor contained in it. At the end, the output dry flow enters to GC device. The methane conversion is calculated as follows: M e t h a n e C o n v e r s i o n = F C H 4 i n − F C H 4 o u t F C H 4 i n F C H 4 o u t ( mol . s − 1 ) a n d F C H 4 i n are outlet streams and the methane flow rate in the inlet, respectively. Because there was no carbon monoxide formation in the experiments, selectivity of carbon monoxide for all examinations was assumed zero. 3 Results and discussion The crystalline structures of all catalysts were studied using the X-ray diffraction analysis, and the responses are illustrated in Fig. 3. As can be seen, crystalline phases are formed in all catalyst structures. The average crystalline size of the samples is investigated by Scherrer's equation and given in Table 1 . The diffraction patterns of the NiAl2O4 and NiFe2O4 samples are presented in Figs. 2 a and 2b, respectively. The peaks at 2θ = 36.963°, 59.599° and 65.495° can be related to nickel aluminum oxide (JCPDS 00–001–1299). Moreover, those located at 43.381°, 63.024° and 75.598° refer to the nickel oxide phase with the cubic structures (JCPDS 01–073–1519). In addition, the peaks at 19.331, 31.820° and 45.619° with low intensity show the presence of cubic aluminum oxide in the composition (JCPDS 00–047–1292). The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 30.263°, 43.473°, 53.888° and 62.728° can be related to the presence of NiFe2O4 (JCPDS 00–003–0875), and the peaks at 2θ= 37.460°, 57.588° and 74.868° are related to iron oxide (JCPDS 01–075–0449). According to Scherrer equation, increasing the peak height increases the crystalline size. By observing Fig. 3 a, it can be stated that NiAl2O4 sample has sharper and narrower peaks compared to NiFe2O4 sample. As a result, NiFe2O4 sample demonstrates smaller average crystalline size (10.13 nm) than NiAl2O4 (11.3 nm). The diffraction pattern of the CuFe2O4 is presented in Fig 2c. The peaks at 2θ= 18.508°, 30.168° and 62.775° indicate the formation of CuFe2O4 compound in sample a (JCPDS 00–025–0283). The presence of peaks at 2θ=33.331°, 41.056° and 56.419° as well as 2θ=36.143°, 43.834° and 58.071° shows the presence of iron oxide (JCPDS 01–084–0308) and copper oxide (JCPDS 01–083–1665) phases, respectively. The peaks of sample CuFe2O4 (Sol gel) are sharper than those of CuFe2O4 (Co-precipitation). The crystalline sizes of CuFe2O4 (Co-precipitation) and CuFe2O4 (Sol gel) samples according to the XRD data and using the Scherrer equation, were achieved 13.20 and 26.70 nm, respectively. In the case of the CoFe2O4 sample (Fig. 2d), the change was also obtained in the XRD pattern of the two samples. The peaks located at 30.273°, 37.281°, 43.473° and 57.168° are related to cobalt iron oxide (JCPDS 00–001–1121). Furthermore, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 24.262°, 33.331°, 41.056°, 349.706°, 54.360°, 64.419°, and 72.403° as well as 2θ =36.687° and 59.084° can refer to the iron oxide (JCPDS 01–084–0308) and cobalt oxide (JCPDS 01–080–1534) phases, respectively. The crystalline sizes of CoFe2O4 (Co-precipitation, Sol gel) are 11.80 and 16.20 nm, respectively. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm versus relative pressure and pore size distributions of catalysts for NiAl2O4, NiFe2O4, CoFe2O4 and CuFe2O4 are shown in Fig. 3. The BET results of synthesis catalysts are shown in Table 2 . Regarding the IUPAC classification, the mesoporous materials with H3 hysteresis loops are in the type of IV isotherm category which are assumed by non-rigid aggregates of plate-like particles. However, the pore network contains macro-pores not totally filled with pore condensate. Mesoporous formation is clearly evident in the BJH plots for all catalysts. The formation of the hysteresis loop at the lower relative pressure and the greater slope of the adsorption profile of the NiAl2O4 sample in this catalyst affirmed the existence of smaller pores at this proposed catalyst compared to the experimental ones in the NiFe2O4 catalyst. In addition, by changing the synthesis method, no obvious change was observed in the shape of the isotherms; furthermore, the distribution of pores, shown in Fig. 3, affirmed these mentioned results. These results show that the synthesis method has no change in the structure of the sample and the shape of the pores, and that the particles have an extensive pore size distribution in macro and meso ranges. The morphology and particle size distribution of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 4 . The change in the morphology and the decrease in the particle size are clearly visible in FESEM images, showing that the preparation techniques have an impact on the structure of the catalyst. The particular surface area of the catalysis fabricated by Co-precipitation method is smaller than that of the Sol- gel method. The presence of PEG as surfactant the procedure of catalyst preparation via Co-precipitation method. By using PEG, the nuclear growth, which is significantly affect the size of particles. In fact, the presence of PEG leads to formation of smaller particles and higher surface area [51]. It is clear that the catalyst prepared by the Sol gel method has larger particles than the co-precipitated samples. Furthermore, the pore volume of CuFe2O4 (Cp) and CoFe2O4 (Cp) catalyst is much larger than CuFe2O4 (Sg) and CoFe2O4 (Sg). In order to ensure uniform distribution of catalysts, SEM micrograph with 1 micrometer resolution is presented in Fig 5 . As it can be seen in this figure, the samples are uniform, which is a good property for the catalytic performance. As can be seen, the active metals in the catalysts synthesized by Co-precipitation method had a more uniform distribution than the one synthesized by sol gel method. EDX analysis of the samples are also illustrated in Fig 6 . The reduction behaviors of CuFe2O4 and CoFe2O4 samples were considered through H2-TPR analysis, and the reduction curves are displayed in Fig. 7 . The CuFe2O4 as-prepared sample presented three main reduction peaks at ∼ 279, 437, and ∼ 687 °C. The low temperature peak at 279 °C is related to the conversion of the CuFe2O4 into metallic copper and α-Fe2O3 species. In addition, the CuO reduction into copper (Cu2+→ Cu0) occurs at this temperature [52,53]. Simultaneously, the high temperature peaks at 437 and 687 °C are attributed to the sequential reduction of α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 and Fe3O4 to FeO and Fe, respectively [54]. For CoFe2O4 catalyst, the weak shoulder at 335 °C was attributed to the surface cobalt species reduction [55]. As can be seen, three reduction peaks at around 420, 670, and 900 °C are characterized for the CoFe2O4 reduction. The first one is assigned to the Co2+ reduction to metallic cobalt sequentially (Co2+→ Co0). The peaks are observed at higher temperatures due to the promotion by the metal cobalt, and Fe3+ reduction to metallic iron [56]. It should be noted that the peaks for temperatures above 600 °C may have resulted from Fe2+ reduction driven by the existence of cobalt and/or textural qualities [57]. The performance of the synthesized catalysts is shown in Fig. 8 . As it is seen, in all experiments, the catalytic performance improved significantly with increasing temperature. In other words, the performance of the catalyst is directly related to temperature. In the temperature range of 400 to 550 °C, with increasing temperature, the performance of the catalyst has increased with a significant slope. The catalytic tests indicate that in the investigated temperature range, all catalysts displayed 100% selectivity towards CO2, and no CO was perceived during the reaction. In the initial review, the catalysts showed almost the same activity at low temperatures, while the activity of CoFe2O4 was significantly higher than that of other catalysts at high temperatures. NiFe2O4 has the lowest performance compared to other samples because of nickel deactivation, with the metal sintering and coke deposition caused mainly effectively by methane decomposition and Boudouard reaction [58–60]. By replacing aluminum with iron, as shown in Fig. 8, the catalyst activity is increased. As shown in Fig. 8, the catalyst activity increases by replacing aluminum with iron. As demonstrated in the figure, by adding cobalt and copper to the sample instead of nickel, the catalyst activity increased significantly. The cobalt can improve the catalytic features such as resistance to metal sintering and carbon deposition [61]. Decreased activity may be due to agglomeration of copper on the catalyst surface, leading to sharp reduction activities. In addition, slight coke formation also contributes to catalyst deactivation [62]. As shown in Fig. 8, the performance of Co-precipitated catalysts is higher than that of sol-gel-synthesized catalysts. It is also observed that the dispersion of elements in the Co-precipitation method is better than that in sol-gel. It is observed in the SEM analysis that some agglomeration has occurred in the catalysts prepared by sol-gel method, which cause an increase in the particle size and a decrease in the specific surface area, thus reducing the catalyst activity. Fig. 9 depicts the stability of CoFe2O4 (co-participation) in 550 °C during 15 hr at constant GHSV of 14,000 h − 1 and atmospheric pressure. As can be seen in this figure, no important activity loss was achieved during 15 hr and the conversion was constant and the stability was stable which affirmed that the catalyst was inactive. Based on Table 3 , the results of this research have been compared with previously reported methods and more acceptable results have been observed. 4 Conclusions In this study, CoFe2O4, CuFe2O4, NiAl2O4, and NiFe2O4 mixed oxide catalysts were prepared through the Co-precipitation method. The reactor tests revealed the CoFe2O4 and CuFe2O4 samples by 97% and 80% methane conversion had superior performance (at 550 °C, atmospheric pressure, O2/CH4 =2 molar ratio, and GHSV=14,000 h-1 operating condition). For comparison, the CoFe2O4 and CuFe2O4 catalysts were fabricated using a sol-gel procedure and the results ascertain methane conversion reduction to 90% and 73%, respectively. As well, the particle size of the CoFe2O4 and CuFe2O4 catalysts in the sol-gel method has increased to 13.5 nm and 5.6 nm, respectively, which attributed to the particle agglomeration and can be seen in the SEM analysis data. According to H2-TPR analysis, the peaks are presented at higher temperature because of they are mostly promoted by the cobalt. With the existence of cobalt or textural qualities, Fe3+ reduction to metallic iron can be observed, and the peaks for temperatures above 600 °C may have resulted from Fe2+ reduction-driven qualities. In co-precipitated CoFe2O4, according to XRD analysis, the distribution of nanoparticles showed that the amount of crystal size was obtained smaller than sol gel and that the elemental distribution obtained in co-precipitated method was most uniform compared to sol gel method. The presence of Co and Cu leads to an increase in the lattice oxygen, and consequently in the activity. Substituting Co with Cu, due to an increase in the lattice defects and lattice oxygen, leads to an increase in the catalytic activity despite smaller Cu crystalline size in comparison to Co. High catalytic activity of the CoFe2O4 refers to its larger capability for oxygen adsorption even at 500 °C, since activation of oxygen to the surface kinetics-controlled region plays an important role in methane oxidation. The results demonstrated that the CoFe2O4 (Co-precipitation) exhibited the most promising activity for methane's catalytic combustion. coredata.dc:description: In this investigation, co-precipitation (Cp) and sol gel (Sg) technique were employed to fabricate CoFe2O4, CuFe2O4, NiAl2O4 and NiFe2O4 mixed oxide catalysts. The catalytic activity of these catalysts in methane combustion was studied at temperature range of 300 to 550 °C and gas hourly space velocity of 14,000 h − 1. Different analyses including the X-Ray Diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption (BET), Energy Dispersive X-Ray Analysis (EDX), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and H2-TPR analysis were used in order to investigate the structural properties of the catalysts. The small crystal size improves the surface area and catalyst active site, thus increasing the rate of reaction and conversion factor. The results revealed that the method of preparation had an important role in controlling the structural features of the catalysts, resulting in an important difference in catalytic presentation. The reactor tests required CO2 selectivity of 100% for all synthesized catalysts, and the best catalytic activity (97% methane conversion) and structural properties (surface area of 41.81 m2 g − 1 and crystal size of 13.20 nm) was demonstrated by CoFe2O4 (co-precipitation) sample. It was also revealed that catalysts synthesized using sol gel method had agglomeration impact on the surface of the catalyst, leading to an increase in crystalline size and a decrease in catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Evaluation of Co-Fe, Cu-Fe, Ni-Al and Ni-Fe mixed oxides in catalytic combustion of methane: Comparison study and investigating the effect of preparation method
